Award.AwardTitle: A Recurrent Nested Bayesian Non-parametric Model for Real Time Monitoring of Pattern Dependent Surface Topography in Chemical Mechanical Planarization (CMP) Operations

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop a new approach to effectively capture the underlying nonlinear and nonstationary evolution of the multi-dimensional process states in Chemical Mechanical Planarization (CMP) process, to enable early defect detection of pattern dependent surface topography in CMP, i.e., dishing/erosion. The proposed research will: (1) establish the fundamental relationships that connect process abnormalities in CMP with extracted features from online sensor signals, i.e., a mapping between the sensor features with the evolving dishing and erosion, thus, to enable early detection of surface topography related defects; and (2) create a new online predictive model with a novel recurrent nested Dirichlet process (RNDP) model which has a non-parametric property and data-driven nature, and can accurately capture CMP process nonlinearity/nonstationarity and avoid the possible model over- and under-fitting.

If successful, this research will result in a technological breakthrough that can fully utilize/integrate the CMP process data and thus enable early defect detection/alleviation for wafer yield improvement. It is anticipated that this proposal would generate significant contributions toward promoting the technological advances in process monitoring and control for semiconductor industry, leading to a better product (IC) quality and higher process productivity for the CMP process. The new curricula, REU, combined with undergraduate and graduate student mentoring programs, will attract potential students, especially from underrepresented groups, to engineering related research and education by exposing students to both fundamental research and industry practices. Dissemination of research outcomes includes professional presentations and publications, website development, media outreach and student publications, as well as collaboration with industry partners.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcome of this project (1) establishes the fundamental relationships that connect process defects of chemical mechanical planarization (CMP) process with extracted features from online sensor signals; thus, early detection of CMP process defects is accomplished successfully; (2) implements a novel online multi-sensor decision fusion approach for detecting process drifts in CMP, and the information from individual sensor signals are combined into a cohesive decision using the evidence theory; this method of sensor fusion overcomes instances where conflicting information is tendered by different sensors; and (3) develops a model which has a non?parametric property and data?driven nature to capture the complex nonlinear, non-Gaussian dynamics of sensor signal patterns in CMP. This project outcome significantly improves the CMP process monitoring and control by implementing the approaches that are capable of dealing with underlying process complexity and uncertainty. Due to its broad applicability, the outcome could also be potentially applied to other advanced manufacturing processes, such as additive manufacturing.

The project outcome has generated significant contributions in promoting the technological advances in process monitoring and control for advanced manufacturing processes such as CMP. As a practical consequence of this research, the operators can conveniently track the status of a complex manufacturing process in a tractable control chart setting with a small number of sensor features. The research outcome has been integrated with educational activities. For example, two new courses related to sensing and data analytics for advanced manufacturing, have been designed and offered to both undergrad and graduate students.  These new courses have attracted students from underrepresented groups, and exposed them to both fundamental research and industry practices. The project outcomes have been disseminated through professional presentations, such as in Annual Meeting of Institute for Operation Research and Management Science (INFORMS) and Annual conference of Institute of Industrial Engineers (IIE), as well as top journal publications in the related research area, such as IIE Transactions, IEEE Transactions Journal of Automation Science and Engineering, and CIRP Annals Manufacturing Technology.


Last Modified: 11/30/2015
Modified by: Zhenyu Kong
